Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Adaptive responses to urbanization in the tropical lizard Anolis cristatellus
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the process of adaptation to urban environments by the tropical lizard, Anolis cristatellus. Urbanization involves drastic habitat modifications that very frequently has negative effects on biodiversity, but a few plants and animals have the ability to persist and thrive. Understanding how these organisms are adapting to urbanization is therefore necessary for predicting future changes to the biosphere. Prior research has shown that Anolis cristatellus has adapted to urban environment through changes in its morphology and physiology. This project will identify genes associated with that adaptation. the result will be new insights into the genetic basis of rapid contemporary adaptation in this and other species and will inform conservation decisions in a world increasingly transformed by human activity. The project will also train undergraduate students, including individuals from groups underrepresented in the sciences, and will create a citizen science project to catalogue urban wildlife in Puerto Rico.

This research employs a genomic approach to identify previously unknown trait shifts related to urban adaptation. The project will use genomic techniques to target transcribed genes of lizards from urban and forest populations across its native range in Puerto Rico. Three common approaches to detect natural selection at the genetic level will be used: the measurement of between-population differentiation, the identification of selective sweeps, and the identification of gene regions with function-altering polymorphism. These methods will enable the identification of gene regions under selection, differential adaptive responses between urban and forest populations, and parallel adaptive responses between urban populations. In addition, the research will identify functional associations of gene regions under selection and will test for correlations between loci under selection and environmental differences between urban and natural habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how organisms adapt to urban environments is an understudied dimension of global change biology, particularly with regard to the tropical region and reptiles. Although urbanization has negative impacts on many species, some species persist and even thrive in urban habitats. The tropical lizard Anolis cristatellus is abundant in urban and forest environments alike, and it fully exploits the urban habitat space including via extensive use of human structures. This in turn exposes urban lizards to unique natural selection pressures leading to morphological and physiological adaptations to urban environments. For example, we previously demonstrated that urban lizards have longer limbs and more specialized scales on their toepads (used for clinging to smooth surfaces) compared to lizards from forests nearby. We have also shown that there is a functional benefit to these trait differences as they improve sprint performance, giving us a mechanistic understanding of how natural selection may be shaping these traits in urban environments. As urbanization continues to expand and intensify globally, it is increasingly important to determine which species are able to adaptively respond, what environmental factors drive phenotypic change, and the mechanistic and genetic basis of these changes.

The study of urban adaptation is a relatively young field in ecology and evolutionary biology, and many of the possible adaptive responses to urbanization have yet to be documented. In this project, we build on our evidence of adaptation to urban environments in this lizard species by looking for evidence of natural selection at the genetic level. Traditional methods of studying natural selection in the wild rely on capture-mark-recapture methods that are extremely time consuming and have inherent limitations. A genomic approach to measuring natural selection addresses many of these issues. Such an approach requires no assumptions about which traits may be under selection, meaning that adaptive responses that are unanticipated or in difficult to measure traits are much more readily detected. The genomic approach is thus capable of providing a more complete picture of the many ways organisms are adaptively responding to urbanization. 

In Anolis cristatellus we looked for genomic evidence of natural selection using a relatively new molecular method called exon capture. By testing for signatures of selection in the coding regions of genes (exons) we can identify a broad range of traits that are changing in urban populations, for instance, those related to morphology, physiology, and cognition. As the study of urban evolution is just beginning to take off, this is a timely and valuable contribution to the field. Our results will help identify new areas of research on urban evolution and help us to better understand the genetic basis of rapid adaptation. Overall, this project adds to a comprehensive and integrative assessment of urban adaptation that addresses adaptive trait shifts, their functional consequences, and natural selection resulting in genetic differences. 

In addition to the scientific results, this award contributed to the professional development of two graduate and two undergraduate students, all of whom are female or members of underrepresented minorities in STEM. We will continue to share our results in traditional channels (peer-reviewed scientific publication, lectures, conferences) as well as non-traditional channels (blogs and non-scientific media).
